Extensions

Extensions allow you to extend an existing class or value type. You can do everything in an extension you could do in the initial definition.

Extending

The syntax is:

extension âŸ¶ ğŸ‹ type-identifier type-body

You can also extend classes from other packages. For example:

Circumvent circular dependencies

Extension can also be used to circumvent circular dependencies. Imagine this problem:

ğŸ‡ ğŸŒ• ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° belongingTo ğŸŒ
ğŸ‰

ğŸ‡ ğŸŒ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° moon ğŸŒ•
ğŸ‰

No matter how you order the class definitions, this example will not compile.

This problem can be solved using extensions:

ğŸ‡ ğŸŒ ğŸ‡ğŸ‰

ğŸ‡ ğŸŒ• ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° belongingTo ğŸŒ
ğŸ‰

ğŸ‹ ğŸŒ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° moon ğŸŒ•
ğŸ‰

Although extensions to classes are practically cost free it is not considered good style to always â€œforward declareâ€ classes to extend them later.
